Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise how language shapes relationships and roles
Elaboration: Understanding that group identities are formed through language that reflects shared values, beliefs and behaviours, and through language choices that engender solidarity such as specialist terminology, acronyms and terms of address; for example, teenage groups and sportspeople have adopted particular words and ways of communicating
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •describing examples of the way their home language shapes relationships and roles

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise how language shapes relationships and roles
Elaboration: Exploring the australian institute of aboriginal and torres strait islander studies map of indigenous australia and identifying language names that inform relationships to country/place

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how layers of meaning can be created when evaluating by using literary devices such as simile and metaphor
Elaboration: Identifying how authors use rhetorical devices that reveal the dark or serious aspects of a topic in humorous or amusing ways; for example, by making a statement but implying or meaning the opposite (irony), exaggerating or overstating something (hyperbole), imitating or mocking something (parody), and making something appear less serious than it really is (understatement)
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •creating a dictionary of rhetorical devices with explanations and examples and provide multiple opportunities to identify and add examples from text extracts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how texts are structured depending on their purpose and how language features vary, recognising that some texts are hybrids that combine different genres or elements of different genres
Elaboration: Recognising how texts such as critical responses to texts, expositions, text interpretations and discussions are typically structured to achieve their purpose
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher modelling and deconstructing a range of short texts to demonstrate how and why language changes to combine different genres in hybrid texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how texts are structured depending on their purpose and how language features vary, recognising that some texts are hybrids that combine different genres or elements of different genres
Elaboration: Discussing how the placement of images and written text in a linear or non-linear way, such as online texts, is used differently in a variety of texts for a purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain how texts are structured depending on their purpose and how language features vary, recognising that some texts are hybrids that combine different genres or elements of different genres
Elaboration: Explaining the structure and language features of texts such as narratives, literary recounts, memoirs, drama scripts, types of poems, formal speeches, comparisons and creative responses, discussions and debates, and explaining how these structures and language features support their purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how cohesion in texts is improved by strengthening the internal structure of paragraphs with examples, quotations and substantiation of claims
Elaboration: Writing paragraphs of extended length that explain, substantiate and exemplify a particular viewpoint
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelling and deconstructing of paragraph structures to demonstrate how cohesive links, examples, quotations and evidence strengthen a point or argument

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Examine a variety of clause structures including embedded clauses that add information and expand ideas in sentences
Elaboration: Evaluating how speechmakers influence audiences though embedded clauses to add information
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •multiple opportunities to practise deconstructing sentences and identifying clause structure, with the complexity of the sentences appropriate to students’ level of English language proficiency

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Examine a variety of clause structures including embedded clauses that add information and expand ideas in sentences
Elaboration: Exploring how clauses and embedded clauses can be used to express ideas more succinctly

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand the effect of nominalisation in texts
Elaboration: Highlighting examples of nominalisation in a range of texts including informative texts and explaining the impact on content and tone
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •creating tables of nominalisations to show both the verbs and nouns from which they originated and adding examples to the table from texts read in class

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand the effect of nominalisation in texts
Elaboration: Nominalising relevant verbs in a series of sentences and discussing the impact of the change in tone on potential audiences

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Investigate how visual texts use intertextual references to enhance and layer meaning
Elaboration: Identifying intertextual references in advertisements and discussing their impact on layering meaning; for example, the interrelationship of words and images
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •including visual texts that reflect a range of cultural backgrounds

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify and use vocabulary typical of academic texts
Elaboration: Identifying the vocabulary of academic report writing on a topic; for example, the use of words such as "evidence", "consequence", "contradiction" and "acknowledge" for the topic "sustainability"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •scaffolded activities that focus on short academic texts, highlighting and explaining examples of abstract words typically used in these texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify and use vocabulary typical of academic texts
Elaboration: Identifying the vocabulary of academic report writing on a topic; for example, the use of words such as "evidence", "consequence", "contradiction" and "acknowledge" for the topic "sustainability"
EALDElaboration: •using bilingual dictionaries and clarify understanding with peers who share the same home language

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify and use vocabulary typical of academic texts
Elaboration: Comparing and contrasting vocabulary choices in academic texts, considering how they are used to create precise information or convey abstract ideas

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand and use punctuation conventions including semicolons and dashes to extend ideas and support meaning
Elaboration: Creating dialogue in drama showing interruptions, asides and pauses for effect
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •clear explanation of both the symbol and the function of punctuation as students may have different symbols in their home language.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the ways that ideas and points of view may represent the values of individuals and groups in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Discussing representations of characters from historical contexts in literary texts; for example, discussing the romantic representation of the australian swagman and the values it reflects
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •clear explanations of how a character may be represented to reflect societal values, for example through dialogue, character development or a character’s actions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the ways that ideas and points of view may represent the values of individuals and groups in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Discussing representations of characters from historical contexts in literary texts; for example, discussing the romantic representation of the australian swagman and the values it reflects
EALDElaboration: •wherever possible use a text by an Australian author or illustrator of that cultural background

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the ways that ideas and points of view may represent the values of individuals and groups in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Explaining attitudes and ideas about the natural world in literary texts drawn from contexts different to their own

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explain the ways that ideas and points of view may represent the values of individuals and groups in literary texts, drawn from historical, social and cultural contexts, by first nations australian, and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Explaining the ways texts by first nations australian authors represent unique ways of being, knowing, thinking and doing

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Share opinions about the language features, literary devices and text structures that contribute to the styles of literary texts
Elaboration: Comparing reviews of a literary text and evaluating opinions that challenge or support personal opinions
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelling, building and recording metalanguage required to discuss language features and language required to state an opinion, for example ‘I would say’, ‘It seems to me that...’, ‘In my view’

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Share opinions about the language features, literary devices and text structures that contribute to the styles of literary texts
Elaboration: Reflecting on and evaluating opinions and arguments about aspects of literary texts including characterisation, setting and plot

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Explain how language and/or images in texts position readers to respond and form viewpoints
Elaboration: Discussing how a complex picture book combines words and images to position readers to respond
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •clear explanations of how language can be used to evoke a response in readers, for example identifying the descriptive language in “The girl’s cries were heart-breaking and her face had a look of hopelessness on it' that positions the reader to feel sympathy for this character

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Explain how language and/or images in texts position readers to respond and form viewpoints
Elaboration: Sharing opinions about how a film positions the viewer to respond to a character

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify intertextual references in literary texts and explain how the references enable new understanding of the aesthetic quality of the text
Elaboration: Identifying intertextual references through allusion or quotation in written texts and discussing how knowledge of other texts influences the reader's understanding and appreciation
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher-supported discussions of intertextual references with explanations of a reference in its original form and the link to the newer text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how language features such as sentence patterns create tone, and literary devices such as imagery create meaning and effect
Elaboration: Recognising that tone is influenced when an author uses active or passive voice
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to hear a range of tones in spoken texts and deconstruction of language features used to create tone in written text (e.g. explanation of the difference between passive and active voice that impact tone)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how language features such as sentence patterns create tone, and literary devices such as imagery create meaning and effect
Elaboration: Examining how writers use terse and relatively simple language choices or more elaborate and complex syntax, and how these influence meaning

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how language features such as sentence patterns create tone, and literary devices such as imagery create meaning and effect
Elaboration: Recognising that first nations australian authors use words and language to set tone when writing or speaking about specific themes; for example, words used to set the tone when writing or speaking about country/place

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that experiment with language features and literary devices for particular purposes and effects
Elaboration: Creating short stories focusing on characters and dialogue
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •deconstruct and jointly construct model texts to show how the literary devices and language features can be used to create a new text with similar features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that experiment with language features and literary devices for particular purposes and effects
Elaboration: Combining literary devices to evoke a reader response

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that experiment with language features and literary devices for particular purposes and effects
Elaboration: Collaborating with a peer, which may include using online spaces, to write a short script with 2 characters, focusing on dialogue choices for each character

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts that experiment with language features and literary devices for particular purposes and effects
Elaboration: Editing the imagery and word choices when creating a literary text and reflecting on the effect of those changes

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how texts reflect contexts
Elaboration: Identifying and explaining how social media texts reflect the context in which they are created
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of texts from a range of cultural backgrounds including those of EAL/D students in the class

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how texts reflect contexts
Elaboration: Identifying how speeches for reconciliation reflect the context in which they are created

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills for identified purposes and situations, including when supporting or challenging the stated or implied meanings of spoken texts in presentations or discussion
Elaboration: Participating in pair, group, class, school and community speaking and listening situations, including informal conversations, discussions, debates and presentations
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •sentence starters to support discussion and demonstrations of language used to support or challenge ideas and meanings, e.g. ‘In the same way...’, ‘Similarly...’, ‘In contrast...’, ‘Whereas...’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills for identified purposes and situations, including when supporting or challenging the stated or implied meanings of spoken texts in presentations or discussion
Elaboration: Listening to a conversation or speech, identifying the point being made, and explaining the tone and manner of presentation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills for identified purposes and situations, including when supporting or challenging the stated or implied meanings of spoken texts in presentations or discussion
Elaboration: Using effective strategies for dialogue and discussion in range of formal and informal contexts, including speaking clearly and coherently and at appropriate length, asking questions about stated and implied ideas, and restating and summarising main ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate the ways that language features vary according to the purpose and audience of the text, and the ways that sources and quotations are used in a text
Elaboration: Evaluating an author's use of language features to present an opinion about those features
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelled deconstruction of a range of texts showing how quotations have been used to support an author’s idea or argument

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse and evaluate the ways that language features vary according to the purpose and audience of the text, and the ways that sources and quotations are used in a text
Elaboration: Evaluating the use of sources and quotations and presenting an opinion about how an author has supported an idea

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how authors organise ideas to develop and shape meaning
Elaboration: Identifying the structure of ideas in a range of texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •concept maps to visually represent the organisation of ideas in a text or graphic outlines to trace the development of an idea through a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how authors organise ideas to develop and shape meaning
Elaboration: Examining texts that structure ideas according to proposition and support, cause and effect, and compare and contrast, and determine their effectiveness

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how authors organise ideas to develop and shape meaning
Elaboration: Exploring texts that attempt to solve problems in a particular way; for example, organising information by considering strengths as well as problems that arise from an approach

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Analyse how authors organise ideas to develop and shape meaning
Elaboration: Analysing how the organisation of a webpage shapes its meaning

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to interpret and evaluate ideas in texts
Elaboration: Reflecting on content by connecting and comparing information across and between texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •explanation of comprehension strategies using familiar texts with accessible content and language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to interpret and evaluate ideas in texts
Elaboration: Reflecting on content by connecting and comparing information across and between texts
EALDElaboration: •use of visuals such as graphic organisers or retrieval charts to help students identify and organize ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to interpret and evaluate ideas in texts
Elaboration: Determining and applying criteria for evaluating the content of a website; for example, criteria for content and website purpose and its effectiveness

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring, questioning and inferring to interpret and evaluate ideas in texts
Elaboration: Analysing the selection and composition of an image in a text and evaluating its effect on the credibility of the story

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising and expanding ideas, and selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Experimenting with and editing text structures and language features; for example, paragraph order and content, and language choices to refine and clarify ideas
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher–supported deconstruction of model texts, modelling of planning for writing and joint construction of sample paragraphs or texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising and expanding ideas, and selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Experimenting with and editing text structures and language features; for example, paragraph order and content, and language choices to refine and clarify ideas
EALDElaboration: •guided or shared editing of texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising and expanding ideas, and selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Selecting vocabulary to position and persuade the reader; for example, adjusting language to show or acknowledge power

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising and expanding ideas, and selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Editing for accuracy of grammar, spelling and punctuation, and for meaning by experimenting with different order of ideas, a range of sentence structures, literary devices and vocabulary to clarify meaning for academic texts where appropriate

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish written and multimodal texts, organising and expanding ideas, and selecting text structures, language features, literary devices and visual features for purposes and audiences in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Using conceptual maps or journals to plan and reflect on each stage of creating a written or multimodal text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations for audiences and purposes, selecting language features, literary devices, visual features and features of voice to suit formal or informal situations, and organising and developing ideas in texts in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Integrating multimodal features in a spoken presentation to support the audience's understanding
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher deconstruction of language, visual and multimodal features of model presentations.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations for audiences and purposes, selecting language features, literary devices, visual features and features of voice to suit formal or informal situations, and organising and developing ideas in texts in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Integrating multimodal features in a spoken presentation to support the audience's understanding
EALDElaboration: •the opportunity to present in smaller groups to build their confidence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations for audiences and purposes, selecting language features, literary devices, visual features and features of voice to suit formal or informal situations, and organising and developing ideas in texts in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Choosing vocabulary and sentence structures, and using literary devices such as similes, metaphors and personification to meet perceived audience needs; for example, when debating a topic or creating a voiceover for a media presentation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations for audiences and purposes, selecting language features, literary devices, visual features and features of voice to suit formal or informal situations, and organising and developing ideas in texts in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Selecting features of voice, such as tone, volume, pitch and pace, with particular attention to the effects these may have on audience reaction and acceptance of the ideas presented

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver spoken and multimodal presentations for audiences and purposes, selecting language features, literary devices, visual features and features of voice to suit formal or informal situations, and organising and developing ideas in texts in ways that may be imaginative, reflective, informative, persuasive and/or analytical
Elaboration: Collaborating with peers to develop a persuasive advertising campaign about a contemporary issue

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Apply learnt knowledge to spell accurately and to learn new words
Elaboration: Understanding the different ways complex words are constructed, and drawing on morphemic knowledge and knowledge of unusual letter combinations when spelling these words

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Apply learnt knowledge to spell accurately and to learn new words
Elaboration: Understanding where to obtain the spelling of aboriginal language words and torres strait islander language words; for example, the australian institute of aboriginal and torres strait islander studies map of indigenous australia, and the local first nations australian community
